sections.title: Basic Word Order (SVO)
sections.explanation: Ukrainian generally follows Subject-Verb-Object (SVO) order, similar to English. However, Ukrainian word order is more flexible because cases show the grammatical role of each word.

exercises.prompt: What is the standard word order in Ukrainian?
exercises.explanation: Like English, Ukrainian uses SVO as the default word order.

exercises.hint: Subject comes first in basic SVO

sections.title: Flexible Word Order
sections.explanation: Because Ukrainian uses cases to mark grammatical roles, you can rearrange words for emphasis. Moving something to the beginning or end of a sentence gives it emphasis. '–ö–Ω–∏–≥—É —è —á–∏—Ç–∞–≤' emphasizes 'the book'.

examples.en: THE BOOK I read yesterday. (emphasis on book)
YESTERDAY we were in the park.

exercises.prompt: Why can Ukrainian change word order freely?
exercises.explanation: Case endings tell you who is the subject, object, etc., regardless of position.
Moving '–∫–∞–≤—É' to the front emphasizes coffee ‚Äî 'COFFEE is what I love!'

sections.title: Question Word Order
sections.explanation: Yes/no questions in Ukrainian can use the same word order as statements, just with rising intonation. The particle '—á–∏' can optionally start a yes/no question. Question words (—Ö—Ç–æ, —â–æ, –¥–µ, –∫–æ–ª–∏, —è–∫, —á–æ–º—É) typically come first.

exercises.prompt: Which particle optionally starts a yes/no question?
exercises.explanation: '–ß–∏' is the optional question particle for yes/no questions.
